title: 113_hr1069
content: The Act is titled the "TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act" and includes a drug screening and testing program for applicants and recipients of assistance under state TANF programs. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires states to implement a drug testing program for applicants and recipients of assistance under state TANF programs. The program includes screening and testing for illegal drug use among individuals at high risk of substance abuse. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for applicants and recipients of state TANF assistance. States must implement a program to screen individuals for illegal drug use, with random or set intervals for testing after initial screening. Assistance will be denied to individuals who have not been screened or tested for illegal drug use. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires drug screening and testing for state TANF assistance applicants and recipients. Screening is done through an effective survey to identify substance abuse risk, followed by further evaluation if needed. A transition rule applies to individuals already receiving assistance before the program's effective date. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for state TANF assistance applicants and recipients. Screening for illegal drug use is required after the 3rd month of assistance if deemed at high risk, with no waiver authority for this provision. Illegal drug is defined as a controlled substance under the Controlled Substances Act. If assistance is denied, the State must continue to provide for other family members. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for state TANF assistance applicants and recipients. If an individual is denied assistance, the State must continue to provide for other family members. The effective date for the amendments made by this section is one year after the enactment of the Act, with a possible delay if state legislation is required. The State plan must comply with additional requirements imposed by amendments made by this Act. Failure to meet these requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after the State legislature's regular session will not be considered a failure to comply with section 402(a). Each year of a 2-year legislative session is deemed a separate regular session.
